title: AI Can Now Read Your Cat’s Pain
intro: Thanks to researchers, new AI tech is delving into feline feelings to see when cats could need medical help.

transcript.author: Sophie Bushwick:
transcript.text: Can you tell what a cat is thinking, just from looking at it?

transcript.author: Tulika Bose
transcript.text: Probably not! Cats evolved to be solitary hunters stalking their prey, not social animals like us humans.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And that poker face might be handy while you’re out stalking prey, but it’s a real problem if humans are trying to figure out whether their pets are  in pain. So that’s why researchers are trying to read more into feline feelings

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: — [sings] using artificial intelligence!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: —[sings] using artificial intelligence! As they love to do. I’m Sophie Bushwick, tech editor at Scientific American.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: I’m Tulika Bose, multimedia editor.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And you’re listening to Tech Quickly, the version of Scientific American’s Science Quickly podcast that just wants to boop AI on the nose.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Cute. [INTRO MUSIC]

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Right now, if you want to see whether a cat’s in pain, you have to take a quiz called the Glasgow Feline Composite Measure Pain Scale.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: It’s also just called Glasgow scale.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ok, hmmm.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: But The question is, what’s on the scale?

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah, what is on the scale?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Well, I just happen to have printed out a couple copies for us to peruse!

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: You did not.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I did indeed.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Wow

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Take a look, take a look at this.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: This looks like a Buzzfeed quiz for cat pain, but uh —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah, the least favorite kind of Buzzfeed quiz.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah, the least favorite. Ok, wow. So I see some little cartoon cats here.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Uh huh.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: And I see their little ears squashed, or upright —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: — And then you have to say which one is your cat.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah! And then, I see uh, a second little set of cartoon cats here, and their little mouths look to be squished in different ways too.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah, so you choose the picture that best matches the cat. And you also answer questions about its behavior —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: — The cat —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: How it responds to being pet —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ok, ok.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And then each one of those questions gets a little number associated with it. Higher or lower, depending on how much pain it indicates. And then you add it all up at the end to get your pain score.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: [Flips page.] This looks kind of hard actually.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: It’s tricky! I mean can you tell the difference between a cat that is tense / crouched —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: No!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And one that is rigid / hunched?

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: No that would be like the same thing to me!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: It sounds exactly the same.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah, exactly!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: So it’s pretty subjective, you have to make some judgment calls…

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: mmhmmm

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And if you’re not a veterinarian, who sees cats and uses this scale all the time, it could be an issue.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Absolutely. More subjective right?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Mmhmm exactly.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: So the idea is that AI might be able to do better?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Or at the very least, it could do it faster and way more easily than an untrained human could.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: So I know freelance science writer Leila Okahata wrote about a study that put AI to the pain-detection test.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: That’s right. Researchers started with photos of 84 cats that were being admitted to a veterinary/animal hospital in Germany —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: — and then they gave these cats a pain score based on the Glasgow scale that we talked about —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Right —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And also on the amount of pain you’d expect a cat to be in for whatever ailment or injury brought them in, you know like a bone fracture. That’s gonna be pretty painful.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yowch.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: You mean “meow-ch”?

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Uh, no, no I don’t.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [Laughs]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ok. diabolical laugh. Diabolical laugh.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I’m not laughing at the cat’s pain. I’m laughing at the cat’s pun.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Uh, wow. Did you just make another pun?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I can’t help myself.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Oh my gosh, ok, ok.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [Continues laughing.]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ok, ok.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I’m just littering the script with them! [Continues laughing.]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yes you are!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [Continues laughing.] Littering? Litterbox?

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Oh my God. You did it again.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah. Anyway, the photos are labeled with the pain scores, and the researchers fed them into two different machine learning algorithms.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: One broke down each photo in great detail, by examining four dozen specific sites on the cats’ faces. These are called called landmarks.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Got it.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: The second AI program was a deep learning model that just looked at each photo as a whole.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Got it. Moment of truth though — could the AI read the cats’ faces?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: It did pretty well!

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Huh!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: The landmark-based model was 77 percent accurate —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: — and the deep learning one was a little less good. That was 65 percent accurate. But they think the deep learning one could improve if it has more photos to train on—this particular kind of model is really data hungry.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: It needs more pictures of cats.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Exactly. Everyone needs more pictures of cats.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: We all do.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Including AI.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Right! So can we learn anything from the AI about reading our cats’ faces?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah, that’s one of the cool things about this study! So it  turns out that the eyes are not the windows to your cat’s soul. When it comes to accurate pain recognition, you need to look at your cat’s mouth.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: It’s meowth.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Aaaaah! You did it!

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: I did it.  Can we go beyond pain here? Like, is there an AI that can tell me if a cat is happy, or sad, or about to knock a glass of water on my laptop?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: That’s the eventual goal! A researcher who’s not involved in this AI study recently published a paper showing that cats can produce almost three hundred facial expressions.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah like I knew this cat that had this expression when it was going to take a bite of MY sandwich—

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs] That’s very specific.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah. But I feel like that was its sandwich-eating, sandwich-stealing —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Sandwich-eating sandwich steal-ing face. The classic expression.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah! It’s like I’m going to swipe your food, stupid human.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs] I mean I feel like all cats have that expression at all times.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah! Just like, hello, dumb human. Feed me. Give me your stuff.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: I’m taking your bed.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs] — and your laptop.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: — everything that you own.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: — Everything that you own is mine now.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: It’s mine. [CLIP] Cat meow

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: So yeah, once you know that you can recognize these different expressions,

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: This researcher wants to join forces with the AI researchers to create a model that can detect more specific cat emotions based on whatever face it’s making. The goal is to be able to look at an image of the cat and have the AI detect whatever emotion that cat is feeling.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Got it, got it. Ok — But like  I’ve heard that emotion recognition AI is really flawed though.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Oh, for sure. For instance, what do you think I’m feeling now? [makes face]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Hmmm. [pause] Sad. You look sad.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah, Wrong! I’m feeling smug!

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Oh!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: — and sneaky, because I just tricked you into thinking I’m feeling an emotion that I’m not.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: [laughs.] Wow, a politician.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I mean think about it! If I just smile I could be like I’m being a politician, I could be saying ‘oh I feel happy’ or I could be saying ‘Im just being polite’ —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ohhh.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Or it could mean, I’m holding in a fart right now!

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: And the AI — it can’t tell that we’re a bunch of lying liars who lie like that.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting! So the idea is that cats don’t lie about their emotions the way we humans do?

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Well, it’s more that with cats and with other pets we have no way to ask them how they feel

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: So even an imperfect tool, like an emotion recognition AI — it’s valuable because it can help us cross that communication barrier.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Got it.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: The researchers also want to expand their work to study emotions in other animals.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: We’ve also talked on this podcast about using AI to decipher wild animal communication.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Interesting!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: So we might just be a few datasets away from letting our pets practically “talk” to us.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Ok that would be so cool!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yes. I want my pet to talk to me.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Same!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: With its furry little face.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Um — I would love to know when my sandwich was about to be stolen —

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Because this has happened numerous times, Angela!

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: I do worry that when I think my cat — my dog is gazing lovingly into my eyes, it’s really just like [give me a treat!]

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Give me food! Do we really want to know? Do we really want to know.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Yeah. I mean once we open up that Pandora’s catbox —

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Oh my God, litterbox, catbox.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: Schrödinger’s box? Let’s not mention Schrödinger. That guy was a jerk.

transcript.author: Bose
transcript.text: Yeah, no. Furry. Furry little box.

transcript.author: Bushwick
transcript.text: [laughs]

transcript.text: [laughs] [OUTRO MUSIC]
